PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIAN, JAPANESE AND SOUTH KOREAN STOCK NEWS: Telstra (TLS AT) expects to record impairment and writedown of value of legacy assets by around AUD 500mln
content:
AUSTRALIA

Bank of Queensland (BOQ AT) - Co. Chairman Davis is to retire. (Newswires)

Charter Hall Group (CHC AT) - Co. is said to be mulling taking a 50% stake in Chufley Tower lease hold valued at AUD 900mln. (AFR)

Mirvac (MGR AT) - Co. shares have been halted as it confirmed a placement valued at AUD 750mln. (Newswires)

Nufarm (NUF AT) - Co. has opened an internal probe for options on reducing its debt. (Newswires)

Telstra (TLS AT) - Co. expects to record impairment and writedown of value of legacy assets by around AUD 500mln, while it expects restructuring costs to increase to around AUD 800mln from around AUD 600mln. In other news, Co. rolls out Australia’s first 5G service. (Newswires)

Utilities/Energy - Australia government may revive plan for energy companies to reduce wholesale power prices. (Newswires)

Other News - The surge in iron prices could boost Australia’s budget by AUB 4bln. (AFR)

 

JAPAN

IHI Corp (7013 JT) - Co. is expected to target FY2021 free cash flow of JPY 70bln. (Newswires)

Mitsubishi Heavy (7011 JT) - Co. is adjusting its long-delayed Mitsubishi Regional Jet project to focus on a smaller model for the US market. (Nikkei)

Nissan (7201 JT) - Co. CEO said the Fiat-Renault deal may present opportunities. (Newswires)

Suzuki (7269 JT) - Co. Chairman forfeits a year’s pay following mass recall and other top executives face income cuts following the inspection cheating scandal. (Nikkei)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Asiana Airlines (020560 KS) - Aekyung hires Samsung Securities (016360 KS) for Asiana bid. (Newswires)

Hanjin Heavy Industries & Construction (097230 KS) - Co. is planning to sell KRW 182.3bln of assets. (Newswires)

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

China’s State Planner NDRC said the nation will prioritise domestic demand for rare earths but are willing to meet other nation's reasonable demand, while China Global Times Editor Hu Xijin earlier suggested that China are seriously considering restricting rare earth exports to the US. (Newswires/Global Times)

US-China talks hit a snag because the US side kept adding new demands in the late stages of the negotiations which would directly affect China’s political and social stability, while Beijing was particularly angered by the additional tariffs and what it saw as an attempt to shift the blame to China. according to Chinese press reports citing sources. (SCMP)

The trade dispute could be a turning point for the China to strengthen independent innovation and reduce its dependence on imported technology, while China has many leverages to use in order to master its own fate according to reports. (Xinhua)

 

UK/EU

Officials suggested German Chancellor Merkel is determined to stay in power up to 2021, as she believes that her chosen successor Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer is not up to the job. (Newswires)

  • EU Economic Sentiment (May) 105.1 vs. Exp. 104.0 (Prev. 104.0, Rev. 103.9) 
  • EU Industrial Sentiment (May) -2.9 vs. Exp. -4.3 (Prev. -4.1, Rev. -4.3) 
  • EU Services Sentiment (May) 12.2 vs. Exp. 11.0 (Prev. 11.5, Rev. 11.8) 
  • EU Business Climate (May) 0.30 vs. Exp. 0.4 (Prev. 0.42)
  • EU Consumer Confidence (May) -6.5 vs. Exp. -6.5 (Prev. -6.5, Rev. -7.3)

 

COMMODITIES

A number of countries are reportedly opposing Russia's request to change the OPEC/OPEC+ meeting dates from June to July, according to Energy Intel's Amena Bakr. (Newswires/Twitter)

Chile's Codelco said the US-China trade war has a "phenomenal" impact on copper and that the volatility makes investment decisions harder, while it sees copper demand growing 1.8% and supply growing 1.6% in 2021. (Newswires)

South Africa's Transport Workers Union Satawu are to strike across South African Ports on Thursday and are threatening a total shutdown. (Newswires)

China's Dalian commodity exchange have raised fees for some Iron ore futures contracts starting May 30th. (Newswires) 

 

GEOPOLITICS

France said they have an indication of chemical weapon use in Idlib, Syria. In related news, the US State Department said it is alarmed by Russian and Syrian government airstrikes in North West Syria, while it also commented that the entire weapons of mass destruction programme in North Korea violates the UN resolution. (AFP/Newswires) 

 

US

FOMC Discount Rate Minutes stated that all 12 Fed regional banks supported keeping discount rates steady before 30th April meeting and that no sentiment was expressed for changing the rate, while directors said the FOMC should continue with patience on rate moves. (Newswires)

Canadian Government is to formally present a bill to its parliament on the ratification of the USMCA on Wednesday, according to a source. (Newswires)

US Consumer Confidence (May) 134.1 vs. Exp. 130.0 (Prev. 129.2). (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

Consumer Staples, including Kraft Heinz (KHC), underperformed today, amidst weak Nielsen data. Utilities also suffered, with some traders citing the possibility of end of month MSCI rebalancing. FedEx (FDX) was under pressure on the fall-out from a package dispute with Huawei, in which the freight service shipped items to the wrong address. General Electric (GE) managed to reverse early losses after the automaker announced it would fire 1000 workers in France, much to the consternation of the French government. Total System Services (TSS) caught a bid after a merger between the co. and Global Payments Inc (GPN). Global Payments Inc moved lower. Activision Blizzard (ATVI) jumped higher after receiving an upgrade at Goldman Sachs. Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) soured after the chipmaker announced its 7nm product roadmap at Computex. Competitor Intel (INTC) fell, with Cowen analyst Matthew Ramsey noting the loss of a key advantage it had over Advanced Micro Devices. Mylan (MYL) fell after UBS sharply reduced their PT for the co. Tobacco names, including Altria (MO) and Philip Morris International (PM), fell at the open as studies emerged over the weekend linking flavoured E-cigarettes to certain types of cancer. Beyond Meat (BYND) jumped higher after receiving a flurry of favourable broker initiations. S&P 500 -0.9% at 2802, NASDAQ-100 -0.3% at 7278, Dow Jones -0.9% at 25349.

The Tplex traded directionally higher on Tuesday, with new contract highs made in Ultra longs, USM9s, Ultras and TYM9s. Looking at the curve, the belly saw the largest fall in yields, with 7-year yields posting 19-month lows; the front-to-belly saw curve flattening with the 2s/10s spread settling c. 2bps flatter, whereas the 10/s/30s steepened by c. 1.3bps. Elsewhere, the US 2-year auction was solid, stopped through the screens by 1bps (high yield 2.125%). Cover was firm at 2.75x (highest since August 2018), above recent averages and the previous. Dealer take down fell beneath recent averages as well as the prior (26.2%, the lowest since Jan 2018vs 36.1% six-auction average), leaving directs with 27.2% (largest since May 2016, six auction average 16.4%), and indirects with 46.6% (slightly beneath the 47.6% six-auction average). The 5-year auction was more in line with recent auctions, stopping through the screens by 0.2bps on a high yield of 2.065% (lowest yield since October 2017), covered 2.38x (six auction average 2.36x). Dealers took a touch below recent averages at 24.2% (largest share since January, six auction average 26.3%), directs took 18.4% (highest since February, and up from 15% six-auction average), leaving indirects with 57.5% (a shade beneath the 58.6% six-auction average). US T-note futures (M9) settled 16 ticks higher at 125-12+.

subject: UK opposition Labour Party leader Corbyn is facing defiance from Labour grandees as Charles Clarke and Bob Ainsworth dared him to expel them after they admitted voting for other parties in European elections
France President Macron says he wants two women and two men for the top four EU jobs
EU Council President Tusk says we did not discuss names tonight, just the process
US MARKET WRAP - 28 MAY 2019: SPX tests 2800; Italy/EU budget dispute escalates
content:
* SNAPSHOT: Equites down, Treasuries up, Dollar up, Crude mixed.

* REAR VIEW: China maintains rare earth minerals threat, Italy’s Salvini doubles down on intention to challenge EU rules, Strong US Consumer Confidence data, Strong EZ Sentiment data, Consumer Staples and Utilities Sectors hit

* WEDNESDAY: GE Import Prices, FR GDP Q1, GE Employment Data, BoC Rate Decision, US API, BoJ’s Kuroda, ECB’s Mersch, Visco, Rehn, RBNZ Financial Stability Report

* US/CHINA TRADE: The South China Morning Post, shedding light on the breakdown in US-China trade talks, said they hit a snag due to the US side adding new demands in the late stages of the negotiations, some of which would directly affect China’s political and social stability, the newspaper claimed. Beijing was particularly angered by the additional tariffs, and what it saw as a US attempt to shift the blame onto China. In the US morning, the seemingly ubiquitous Global Times editor stated that China is seriously considering restricting rare earth exports to the US, and it may also take other countermeasures in the future; these suggestions have been rubbished by analysts in recent weeks (China would be cutting off its nose to spite its face, essentially), although his comments were later followed by a Chinese official, who stated that the nation will prioritise domestic demand for rare earths but are willing to meet other nation's reasonable demand, according to China's State Media, leaving open the possibility that China will weaponise rare earths.

* BREXIT: Current Chancellor Hammond, speaking about the Conservative leadership race, said any PM pursuing a no-deal Brexit would face a confidence vote; it is a sign that there are still pro-EU lawmakers in the UK Parliament that would work to prevent any hard-line Tory leader attempting to leave in October without a deal. Elsewhere, UK PM met with European Council President Tusk today to update him on her resignation, to reiterate that it had been agreed with the EU that the Withdrawal Agreement will not be reopened, and that no deal has remained the legal default.

* ITALY: The possibility of a showdown between Italy and the EU over the latter’s debt was in the spotlight for a second day (following Monday’s reports Italy could be fined up to EUR 4bln for excessive debt levels). Italian Deputy PM Salvini reiterated his critiques of EU fiscal rules; saying rules should be aimed at cutting unemployment instead of keeping deficits below 3%, whilst confirming his intention to propose his EUR 30bln flat tax to the cabinet and vowing not to agree to increase taxes in his letter to the EU. Salvini also proposed a conference to discuss the role of the ECB and its role in guaranteeing government debt, while Italian PM Conte weighed in, saying he is reviewing the ECB’s mandate to guarantee public debt as an open dossier that requires a lot of work. European Commissioner for Economic and Financial Affairs Moscovici said that he is not in favour of sanctioning Italy, whilst European Commission Vice President Dombrovkis said he cannot confirm reports about potential fines on Italy and the Commission will next week assess the compliance of member states looking into FY 19/20.

* EU SUCCESSION: EU leaders meet at an informal summit tonight in Brussels to discuss the Election results and likely the EU’s top jobs, particularly the European Commission President and head of the ECB. The main frontrunner for the role of EC President remains EPP head Manfred Webe, whose claim is supported by the Spitzenkandidaten process (which enjoys EP support). French President Macron, however, has said he would prefer European Commissioner for Competition Vestager, EU’s Chief Brexit Negotiator Barnier or EC VP Timmermans (who also enjoys support from the Spanish PM and EU Parliament Social Democrat Leader Bullmann). Whoever takes the ECB top spot will likely depend on who gets the role of EC head; Villeroy de Galhau and Oli Rehn are in the running, but Weidmann remains a potential if Weber fails to get the EC President job. Click here for a more in-depth analysis.

* GEOPOLITICS: France said they have an indication of chemical weapon use in Idlib, Syria. The US State Department later said it is alarmed by Russian and Syrian government airstrikes in North West Syria and attacks on civilians and public infrastructure are a reckless escalation of the conflict. On Iran, the US State Department noted that it was not aware of an Iran backed channel. Elsewhere, the Qatari Foreign Minister met with Iranian Deputy Foreign Minister in Doha to review developments in the Middle East and expressed concerns over recent escalations. The Iranian Deputy Foreign Minister also said Iran is ready to engage in talks with the Gulf states regarding stability of the region but did not mention talks with the US. On North Korea, the US State Department commented that North Korea’s entire weapons of mass destruction programme is a violation of the UN resolution, before switching to the Libya conflict to note that the Hafta campaign can play an important role in Libya.

* US CONSUMER CONFIDENCE: US Consumer Confidence rose to 134.1 in May (exp. 130.0, prev. 129.2); jobs “plentiful” increased from 46.5% to 47.2%, while those claiming jobs are “hard to get” declining from 13.3% to 10.9%, thus bringing the gap between Jobs plentiful and Jobs hard to get from 33.2% to 36.3%, auguring well for next week’s Employment Situation Report. Oxford Economics notes that, despite the recent escalation in trade tensions, consumers continued to grow more confident about both the present situation and the near-term outlook, after the headline rose to a six-month high, nearing this cycle’s peak. “The robust labour market is keeping consumers upbeat and points to a modest spending rebound in Q2,” Oxford Economics says, “while we expect consumer spending to firm in Q2, momentum is likely to remain on a downward trend through the rest of the year,” the consultancy writes, noting that real disposable income growth has cooled from above 3% Y/Y in Q4, down to 2.3% in March as the impact of fiscal stimulus has faded. “This will weigh on real spending momentum, which we expect to fall to around 2% Y/Y in Q4 2019, down from 2.6% in Q4 2018,” OxEco says.

* EZ SENTIMENT: Headline beta the consensus (105.1, exp. 104.0, prev rev 103.9), with both industrial and services confidence rising. However, the Business Climate Indicator fell to 0.30 from 0.42 (cons 0.4). Pantheon Macroeconomics said the survey has been a poor leading indicator for GDP growth in recent quarters; it has captured the direction in growth, but not the overall pace. “That said, this month’s increase is the first month-to-month rise since June last year,” PM says, “this is not conclusive evidence of anything, but it is a much welcome change from the recent uninterrupted decline.”

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (M9) SETTLED 16 TICKS HIGHER AT 125-12+: The Tplex traded directionally higher on Tuesday, with new contract highs made in Ultra longs, USM9s, Ultras and TYM9s. Looking at the curve, the belly saw the largest fall in yields, with 7-year yields posting 19-month lows; the front-to-belly saw curve flattening with the 2s/10s spread settling c. 2bps flatter, whereas the 10/s/30s steepened by c. 1.3bps. Elsewhere, the US 2-year auction was solid, stopped through the screens by 1bps (high yield 2.125%). Cover was firm at 2.75x (highest since August 2018), above recent averages and the previous. Dealer take down fell beneath recent averages as well as the prior (26.2%, the lowest since Jan 2018vs 36.1% six-auction average), leaving directs with 27.2% (largest since May 2016, six auction average 16.4%), and indirects with 46.6% (slightly beneath the 47.6% six-auction average). The 5-year auction was more in line with recent auctions, stopping through the screens by 0.2bps on a high yield of 2.065% (lowest yield since October 2017), covered 2.38x (six auction average 2.36x). Dealers took a touch below recent averages at 24.2% (largest share since January, six auction average 26.3%), directs took 18.4% (highest since February, and up from 15% six-auction average), leaving indirects with 57.5% (a shade beneath the 58.6% six-auction average).

* 7-YEAR PREVIEW: SocGen says the 7-year sector trades fair on the curve vs 5s and 10s, and trades slightly rich against older 7s from a relative value standpoint. The bank notes that the WI is trading beneath all prior auction high yields since September 2017, which is a negative; and accordingly, will likely need to see concession going into the auction on an outright basis. The previous 7-year auction was poor, tailing. However, dealer holdings in the 6- to 7-year bucket are the lowest since October 2018, and may provide marginal support for the auction.

* WTI (N9) FUTURES SETTLE USD 0.51 HIGHER AT USD 59.14/BBL; BRENT (N9) FUTURES SETTLE UNCHANGED AT USD 70.11/BBL: Crude markets came off their highs on Tuesday going into the US session, before reproaching them, in what was a choppy day of trade. Analysts at Citi summarise that ongoing geopolitical risks to supply are also providing some fresh support, and the analysts go on to highlight recent comments from Saudi Arabia that points the finger at Iran for backing Yemen’s Houthi rebels, in addition to ramped up conflict in Libya. It is worth highlighting that option expiry in Brent on Tuesday may dictate some price movement as a result of book squaring; also, the usual API data release for US inventories is delayed by 24 hours due to the closure of US markets on Monday (will be released after market on Wednesday, and DOE data to be released Thursday). Elsewhere, sources reported that supplies of Urals heading to Germany and Poland via Druzhba are planned at 65k tonnes per day following next month's pipeline restart, in July supplies are forecast to return to their normal level of 145k tonnes per day.

* S&P 500 -0.9% at 2802, NASDAQ-100 -0.3% at 7278, Dow Jones  -0.9% at 25349; SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary -0.5%, Consumer Staples -1.8%, Energy -1.1%, Financials -1.1%, Health Care -1.4%, Industrials -1%, Information Technology -0.3%, Materials -0.9%, Telecommunication Services 0.2%, Utilities -1.6%

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Consumer Staples, including Kraft Heinz (KHC), underperformed today, amidst weak Nielsen data. Utilities also suffered, with some traders citing the possibility of end of month MSCI rebalancing. FedEx (FDX) was under pressure on the fall-out from a package dispute with Huawei, in which the freight service shipped items to the wrong address. General Electric (GE) managed to reverse early losses after the automaker announced it would fire 1000 workers in France, much to the consternation of the French government. Total System Services (TSS) caught a bid after a merger between the co. and Global Payments Inc (GPN). Global Payments Inc moved lower. Activision Blizzard (ATVI) jumped higher after receiving an upgrade at Goldman Sachs. Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) soured after the chipmaker announced its 7nm product roadmap at Computex. Competitor Intel (INTC) fell, with Cowen analyst Matthew Ramsey noting the loss of a key advantage it had over Advanced Micro Devices. Mylan (MYL) fell after UBS sharply reduced their PT for the co. Tobacco names, including Altria (MO) and Philip Morris International (PM), fell at the open as studies emerged over the weekend linking flavoured E-cigarettes to certain types of cancer. Beyond Meat (BYND) jumped higher after receiving a flurry of favourable broker initiations.

* BOC PREVIEW: The BOC is expected to keep rates unchanged at 1.75%, with the market expecting the central bank to reiterate a dovish message, despite some upside surprises in data of late. There is no post-meeting press conference nor updated economic projections at this meeting. Click here for in depth analysis.

* FX WRAP: USD moved higher for a second day, DXY finding further support after much better than expected consumer confidence numbers. EUR was marginally softer on the day, moving to the bottom of the recent its recent 1.1175-1.1215 range, as the market eyes the growing prospect of an Italy/EU confrontation. JPY gained some momentum amid a risk off feel during European morning trade, but found support at 109.20 (vs USD) before reversing the move to finish the day marginally higher as US risk assets moved marginally higher. GBP was more-or-less flat, with any downside capped as Chancellor Hammond reminded us that, given parliamentary opposition, a no deal outcome remains unlikely. CAD was weaker ahead of BoC, where the central bank is expected to reiterate a dovish message. TRY was stronger on the day, but unable to substantially break 6.00 (vs USD) to the downside, the turn around also coinciding with news Turkey had asked local banks to purchase more TRY-denominated bonds.

* EUR: Remains slightly sub-1.12, ignoring EU elections, with desks suggesting the currency is paying more attention to US/China trade talks (some suggested this was perhaps a function of a stable yuan fixing overnight, lending stability to the EUR). Italy also a situation to keep track of (widening bund/BTP differentials could pressure the EUR, as seen on Monday), though the single currency largely ignored widening Bund/BTP spreads. Some desks have said they prefer selling rallies overall, and amid the lack of data, there will be attention if 1.11 holds; shorts may be added on a breach, other desks have said. Levels: 1.1055 (YTD low), 1.1100/05, 1.11 (shorts may be added, DB says), 1.1180 (Monday high), 1.1196 (30dma), 1.1215/20 (UBS says good level to short), 1.1265 (last week’s high).

* JPY: Range now seems to be 109-110.50, with some desks suggesting a bias to sell rallies. However, be cautious about month-end demand for USD. EURJPY stable considering scope for potential ramp-up in tensions between EC/Italy. Levels: 108.50 (31 Jan lo), 109.02 (13 May lo), 109.05/15/20, 109.30 (expect bids to emerge like last week), 109.675 (21 May hi), 109.75/80, 110.00 (UBS suggests adding shorts), 110.30 (shorts covering in this area last week), 110.96 (post trade tensions hi)  110.30/35, 112.40 (ytd hi). EURJPY 122.00 break could open the way to 121.50.

* GBP: The rise of the Brexit Party, and a likely pro-Brexit conservative leader keeps GBP under pressure as it raises risks of a no deal Brexit. However, whether or not those fears appear overdone still remain to be seen, given that Parliament is still unlikely to allow a pro-Brexit PM to lead the country out of the EU without a deal, as current Chancellor Hammond reminds us today. Some even remind us that a lot of this narrative is/was already in the price, and accordingly, sharper downside might be limited in absence of a fresh catalyst. Technically, a failure to remain above 1.2725/30 sees the pair drift lower, techs say (and some suggest a good region to add shorts) with a reassessment above 1.2815/20. Levels: 1.2441 (ytd low), 1.2480, 1.2580/85, 1.2600/05 (26 May lo), 1.2645/50, 1.2695/00, 1.2730/50, 1.2754 (weekly hi), 1.2815/20, 1.2870/80. EURGBP levels: 0.8791 (200dma), 0.8693 (100dma), 0.8850 (24 May hi), 0.8867 (61.8% fib Jan-Mar).

* CAD: Range seems to be 1.3370-1.3570. BOC on Wednesday, expected to reiterate the need for accommodation despite the data surprises to the upside. Meanwhile, WTI providing no clear catalyst as it remains around the USD 60 mark. Levels: 1.3255 (200dma), 1.3310 (trend line support), 1.3335/40 (100dma region), 1.34/07 (region to potentially buy the dip, 100dma), 1.3480/00, 1.3500/20 (sell rallies, though breach risks topside breakout).

* AUD: Desks note there has been a failure to extend downside, despite a dovish RBA last week, and bank desks revising their RBA views lower. Bounces might be harder given market expectations of an RBA rate cut on 4 June. Levels: 0.6850 (close below would be bearish, techs say), 0.6865/70 (last week’s bottom), 0.6900/10 (close below would open up technical downside), 0.6945/50 (techs build shorts, reassess short bias above), 0.6970/80, 0.7000/10.

* BRL: Seems to have fared better than other EMFX on Tuesday, despite a tense political situation, and the weekend’s pro-Bolsonaro protests, which were calling for fiscal reforms to be passed; these protests followed others in mid-May, which protested the government’s 30% freeze on discretionary spending for public universities. Last week, economy adviser threatened to resign if pension reform was watered down. Congress is working on its own version of the Bill, and the government is willing to consider it so long as it maintains a high level of fiscal savings (the government sees BRL 1trln over a 10-year period; analysts say there could be a sharp sell-off in Brazilian assets if that figure falls to/below BRL 500bln. GDP data on Thursday is a data point to keep an eye on.

* ZAR: the announcement of the new cabinet has been delayed to later in the week. The candidacy of David Mabuza for reappointment to the role of Vice President is controversial, as he is under a number of graft investigations. Last week’s dovish SARB is not doing much to help the slide, after opening the door to a potential rate cut later in the year, while Eskom’s finances are also a fiscal concern. JPMorgan today recommended a small long in USDZAR. Levels: 14.5865, 14.75.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Usd/G10 pairs rangy, but Lira and Rand break ranks
content:
DXY

The Dollar is struggling to derive any additional impetus from much better than forecast US consumer confidence, as the index holds within a tight 97.877-688 range and inside support and resistance at 97.500 and 98.000, like a 97.541 Fib. However, Usd/majors are mostly flat to firmer, with the CHF and CAD especially weak after mixed data and in advance of the BoC policy meeting on Wednesday. To recap, Q1 GDP topped consensus by some distance, but the trade surplus was narrower than forecast and the Swiss Government downplayed the unexpectedly strong expansion as one-off factors boosted growth. Meanwhile, the Loonie looks cautious ahead of tomorrow’s BoC policy meeting and the possibility that the latest guidance is dovish – see our headline feed for a full preview. Usd/Chf has climbed to just shy of 1.0090, Eur/Chf to within a pip of 1.1275 and Usd/Cad faded around 1.3480. Back to the Buck specically, month end factors may be positive in May for a change as Citi’s preliminary rebalancing model flags a buy, and a particularly strong signal against the Pound.

AUD/NZD 

The Antipodean Dollars are off best levels, but still firm vs their US peer around 0.6935 and 0.6550 with the Aussie clawing back some recent losses ahead of June’s RBA meeting (1/4 point ease completely factored in) and the Kiwi eyeing Wednesday’s RBNZ Financial Stability Review for potential independent impetus.

JPY/EUR/GBP

All narrowly mixed vs the Usd as the Yen retreated from resistance ahead of 109.00 yet again to retest lows circa 109.60, while the single currency continues to hit technical levels around 1.1200 and meet underlying buying interest ahead of recent lows (including the 2019 base just above 1.1100). Fundamentally, Eurozone economic and political impulses remain a weight, with a relatively bleak German outlook for 2019 from the DIHK and Italian-EU divergences on finances resurfacing ahead of next week’s budget review and potential EDP launch. Similarly, Brexit and the UK political void soon to be left by PM May continues to hamper the Pound as Cable trades on the heavy side of 1.2655-1.2700 boundaries and Eur/Gbp holds firm above 0.8800, albeit down from recent peaks.

EM

In stark contrast to the relatively confined parameters mentioned above, the Try and Zar have diverged quite sharply. The Lira has managed to revisit 6.0000 and a bit above vs the Usd in wake of yesterday’s 200 bp RRR tightening and in spite of a marked deterioration in Turkish economic sentiment, but the Rand has been hit hard by renewed political concerns following approval for SA President Ramaphosa to bring back Mabuza into parliament (who is under investigation for fraud, corruption and worse). Usd/Zar is hovering above 14.7000 and has been up over 14.7400. Elsewhere, another marginal move up in the Usd/Cny fix overnight left the spread to Usd/Cnh on a wider trajectory, but the former could be set higher in wake of the PBoC’s move to raise its counter cyclical ‘adjustments’, while prioritising the use of rare earths on the domestic front and potentially restricting exports to the US.

ANALYSIS: European Commission President, and ECB President front-runners
content:
• EC PRESIDENT JOB: Ahead of tonight’s informal summit in Brussels to discuss the Election results and likely the EU’s top jobs, particularly the European Commission President and head of the ECB, a number of frontrunners have emerged for these roles. In spite of the two largest parties, the EPP and S&D, not holding a majority the EPP’s head Manfred Weber remains a key contender due to the Spitzenkandidaten concept. ING notes that on balance Weber’s case is neither stronger nor weaker in the new parliamentary layout. His claim is bolstered by an EP statement which is reportedly to state that there is broad support for the Spitzenkandidaten system, and the Eurosceptics did not outright reject the concept. However, French President Macron has stated that the European Commissioner for Competition Vestager, EU’s Chief Brexit Negotiator Barnier and EC VP Timmermans are the contenders who meet his criteria.
  • ECB PRESIDENT JOB: The other key appointment is who will succeed Draghi as the ECB’s head, with this likely to be heavily influenced by who is appointed to as the European Commission President. Capital Economics highlights that if Weber is appointed then this will effectively block Weidmann. Although, as French President Macron has indicated his support for other candidates, this does create potential for Weidmann. Berenberg, meanwhile, suggests that Weber’s appointment would likely lead to France nominating Villeroy de Galhau as Draghi’s replacement as a consolation to France. Alternatively, Oli Rehn could be appointed as a compromise between Germany and France; particularly in the event that neither Weber or any of the candidates outlined by Macron become the new European Commission President.
  • During this process it is worth bearing in mind that the FT cites Macron as saying that tonight’s discussion should not be of specific names that the discussions should be pertinent to the qualities they are seeking in candidates. ING points out that this process could continue for an extended period of time, assuming European Commission President Juncker is prepared to remain as caretaker until the process is resolved.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 28th May 19
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

DOW

Apple (APPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) – Huawei’s CEO said that the Chinese tech firm would oppose any retaliation against Apple. Elsewhere, Apple is reportedly to be sued over selling users’ iTunes data, as well as their personal data. In other news, Pegatron, a Taiwanese supplier for Apple, will invest USD 1bln in an Indonesia factory to produce iPhone chips. Elsewhere, Apple is to acquire startup Tueo Health, a startup which helps parents monitor asthma symptoms in sleeping kids. Apple also launched its new iPod Touch, which will start at USD 199. Finally, Citi lowered its price target for the iPhone maker to USD 205 from USD 220 on concerns that the US/China trade dispute will affect demand for the iPhone in China.

Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) is being targeted by Oklahoma State in an opioid trail. Another defendant, Teva (TEVA) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals), has settled a similar case for USD 85mln. Elsewhere, the drug maker was initiated with a buy at Goldman Sachs, with analyst Terence Flynn suggesting that J&J’s diversified portfolio is a strength as it reduces the co.’s exposure to Medicare/Medicaid.

Pfizer (PFE) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) announced that its Phase 3 study of its LYRICA drug did not meet its primary endpoint. Elsewhere, the drug maker was initiated with a conviction buy at Goldman Sachs, with analyst Terence Flynn optimistic on 2021 revenue.

Boeing’s (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) - The return of the aircraft maker’s 737 MAX faces further delays after the FAA opted to expand its review to include emergency procedures used by pilots on earlier models of the plane.

Walmart (WMT) (Consumer Staples/Hypermarkets & Super Centres), the FT reports, is facing calls to change executive pay, the composition of its boardroom and the hypermarket chain’s approach to sexual harassment. Potential Democratic 2020 candidate Bernie Sanders is expected to attend.

NASDAQ 100

Alphabet (GOOG, GOOGL) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services), the BBC reports, did not refund advertisers billed for fraudulent activity for years.

Amazon (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) had its price target raised at Cowen to USD 2,500 from USD 2,400, given the positive results from its recent cloud survey.

Facebook (FB) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) – Canada says the tech co. has agreed to help boost the security of Canada’s upcoming October elections by upping the removal of fake accounts and bots. Elsewhere, CEO Zuckerberg and COO Sandberg will not appear at a hearing in Ottawa, having been summoned by the Canadian parliament, now risking being held in contempt. In other news, with Facebook facing 11 data probes in Ireland, following the implementation of new EU data protection regulations last year, Twitter (TWTR) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services), Microsoft’s (MSFT) (Information Technology/Systems Software) LinkedIn and Alphabet (GOOG, GOOGL) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) will also be targeted.

Tesla (TSLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) is reportedly considering pricing the Model 3 between 300-350k Yuan before subsidies.

S&P 500

Archer Daniels Midland (ADM) (Consumer Staples/Agricultural Products) is recalling all five-pound bags of Baker’s Corner All Purpose Flour (sold in Aldi) on concerns that they may contain E.coli, which was discovered during testing.

FedEx (FDX) (Industrials/Air Freight & Logistics) – Huawei is reportedly reviewing its relationship with the US freight service after it claimed packages were diverted away from their Huawei destinations in Asia to the US and there were attempts to reroute other packages. The Editor of China’s Global Times weighed in, commenting "FedEx (FDX) has mistakenly diverted Huawei packages to the US. s this shockingly bad service or is it doing dirty work for the US government?". FedEx has formally apologised to Huawei.

General Electric (GE) (Industrials/Industrial Conglomerates) announced plans to cut 1000 jobs in France, despite France’s Finance minister urged the automaker not to close any sites.

Global Payments Inc (GPN) (Information Technology/Data Processing & Outsourced Services), Total System Services (TSS) (Information Technology/Internet Software & Services) have agreed on a stock merger of equals, a deal which values TSS at USD 21.5bln. The merger has been approved by both boards.

Nasdaq (NDAQ) (Financials/Financial Exchanges & Data) has withdrawn its offer to buy Norway’s Oslo Bors.

OTHER

Alibaba (BABA) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) is reportedly weighing a second listing, in Hong Kong, that would raise a further USD 20bln in equity finance.

Booz Allen Hamilton Holding Corp (BAH) (Information Technology/IT Services) (USD) reports Q1 19 adj. EPS 0.64 (exp. 0.63), Revenue 1.78 (exp. 1.74bln). FY20 adj. EPS view 2.90-3.05 (exp. 3.00).

Elbit Systems Ltd (ESLT) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) (USD) reports Q1 19 EPS 1.54 (exp. 1.24), Revenue 1.02bln (exp. 0.98bln). Expects FY19 Revenue to be above 4bln (exp. 4.37bln).

Fiat Chrysler (FCA IM)/ Renault (RNO FP) – On Monday, Fiat Chrysler has submitted the proposal for a transformative merger with Renault wherein both companies will own 50% of the group each with balanced governance structure and majority of the board of directors being independent. FCA says there will be no plant closures as a result of the merger. Co. sees in excess of EUR 5bln estimated annual run rate synergies incremental to the existing Renault-Nissan-Mitsubishi alliance. FCA says the merger would have a strong balance sheet. Renault confirmed the receipt of a proposal from FCA regarding a 50/50 merger transaction. Both companies opened in excess of 10% higher on Monday.

Momo Inc (MOMO) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) (USD) reports Q1 19 EPS 0.62 (exp. 0.55), Revenue 0.555 (exp. 0.53bln).

Uber (UBER) (Industrials/Rail & Roads) board director Ryan Graves announced his intention to resign as of 27th May 2019.

subject: Talking Crude: Prices continue to pare back last week's nosedive
content:
• Oil prices continue to trace back some of last week’s large losses on Tuesday, taking a breather from the demand concerns that consumed participants. News flow has been light, but amid US President Trump’s visit to Japan, it was reported he had asked his Japanese counterpart PM Abe to help him establish a summit with Iran. However, later an Iranian spokesperson said that the Persian Gulf nation sees no prospect for negotiations with the US. 
  • Analysts at RBC take an interesting approach to recent rising crude inventories, "we do not interpret the recent increases as entirely bearish given the majority of builds from the US to consuming Asia have been deliberate and tactical which has, in turn, kept markets tight." It suggests many consuming Asia countries will likely be building stocks due to the sudden cut off from Iranian exports, and more broadly that countries are purposefully and pre-emptively doing so ahead of an increasingly tight physical market. The note goes on to clarify that although calendar spreads, particularly Brent, are in steep backwardation, consuming countries have been stocking up for energy security while forfeiting roll yield, whereas discretionary hubs have been drawing reflecting the tightness.
  • Focusing specifically on the US crude market, in RBC's opinion, "refiners have over recent months, been purposefully bidding up waterborne crude to close the export arbitrage window to prevent the swing barrel from leaving the US Gulf Coast." The note highlights the front-end contango in WTI, which it cites as market fears over recent builds, which it believes "have largely been a function of catching up and rebuilding stocks to prevent inventories from over tightening ahead of peak summer runs."

content:

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 28th May 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European Indices [Euro Stoxx 50 -0.6%] are broadly softer as the region failed to capitalise on the positive Asia-Pac momentum
  • On the trade front SCMP reports that US-China talks hit a snag as the US side ‘kept adding new demands in late stages of the negotiations’
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Consumer Confidence and supply from the US

 

 

EU PARLIAMENTARY ELECTIONS SUMMARY

European elections failed to deliver any drastic upsets; right wing anti-EU parties extended their share of the vote to 23% (vs. 20% in 2014). The Greens & Liberals also put in a strong showing, especially in France, Germany and the UK. In sum, the four largest pro-European parties saw their combined share of the vote fall to 67% from 70%. Focus now falls on the Parliamentary arithmetic with the EPP and S&D unable to achieve a majority alone, as such are likely to team up with the Alliance of Liberals and Democratics. Today’s summit’s focus is on who becomes the next European Commission President with Manfred Weber expected to maintain his claim, though VP Timmermans or Competition Commissioner Vestager are contenders. Further afield is the next ECB President with the relevant summit on 20/21 June.

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were mostly higher but with gains capped as trade slowly picked up from the holiday lull in the US and UK. ASX 200 (+0.5%) was positive with the gains led by the tech sector and as miners cheered the recent upside in commodities including Chinese benchmark iron ore prices which hit record highs. Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) was underpinned by corporate news flow with Tokyo Electron lifted from a JPY 150bln buyback, while Nissan and Mitsubishi Motors gained following the recent merger proposal between alliance partner Renault and Fiat. Hang Seng (+0.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.6%) gained following a substantial liquidity injection of CNY 150bln by the PBoC which placed the ongoing trade uncertainty on the back seat. 10yr JGBs were steady as they mirrored the sideways trade in T-note futures although saw mild support following the results from the 40yr JGB auction where the b/c was firmer than previous and as 40yr yields hit their lowest levels since September 2016.

PBoC injected CNY 150bln via 7-day reverse repos for a net daily injection of CNY 70bln. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8973 (Prev. 6.8924)

PBoC Governor Yi Gang says he is confident that China can keep the Yuan "basically stable"; the benchmark deposit rate will continue to play a important role in the promotion of market-based interest rate reform; the current benchmark lending and deposit rate is at an appropriate level. And the Chinese - US 10yr yield gap is within a relatively comfortable range. Separately, reported that the PBoC are to increase counter cyclical adjustments, Deputy Chief reiterates they are to maintain a prudent monetary policy., Securities Times. (Newswires)

Chinese President Xi said China will increase access to further sectors. There were separate comments from a securities regulator official that China is looking to widen access for foreign investors to the futures market. (Newswires)

US

 

US-China talks hit a snag because the US side “kept adding new demands in the late stages of the negotiations”. They said “some of these would directly affect China’s political and social stability”., according to SCMP citing sources. (SCMP)

- Beijing was particularly angered by the additional tariffs and what it saw as the US’ attempt to shift the blame to China.

Canada is said yo give formal notice to bring legislation forward to ratify new NAFTA treaty. (Newswires)

UK/EU

ECB's Hansson said ECB should be less generous in pricing the TLTROs and that a less generous loan should signal policy normalisation, while he added that tiering ECB rates would risk overcomplicating ECB policy. (Newswires)

ECB's Villeroy (Dovish) says that maintaining low interest rates should be 'completely justified and necessary' given the current economic situation, the impact of lower interest rates on the banking sector should not be overlooked or blown out of proportion. (Newswires)

Italy to cite more revenue spending cuts in their response to the EU., Corriere. While Deputy PM Salvini says the EU could fine Italy EUR 3bln for excessive debt but he will all his energies to fight outdated EU fiscal rules; aim to cut taxes for Italian households with a annual income which is less than EUR 50k, would cost EUR 30bln. (Corriere/Newswires) Subsequently, EU’s Moscovici stated that he is not in favour of sanctioning Italy, and European Commission VP Dombrovskis says he cannot confirm reports on potential Italy fines, Commission will assess the compliance of member states looking into FY 19/20 next week. (Newswires)

Germany DIHK Chamber of Industry and Commerce has reduced their domestic 2019 GDP forecast to 0.6% from 0.9%

- Business outlook has deteriorated since the beginning of the year

- Expectations for foreign business has hit its lowest level in 10 years which is seen as an 'an alarm signal'

Austrian Chancellor Kurz was ousted after losing a no confidence vote. (Newswires)

EU Consumer Confid. Final (May) -6.5 vs. Exp. -6.5 (Prev. -6.5, Rev. -7.3)

 

UK Foreign Secretary Hunt states that any PM who attempts to take Britain out of the EU without a deal will trigger a general election, which leads to the risk of Conservative Party ‘extinction’. Brexit Party leader Farage warning that the new Tory leader must take Britain out of the EU by October, or the Brexit Party will ‘fight every seat’ at the next general election. (Telegraph/Times)

Agustín Carstens, the former finance minister and head of Mexico’s central bank has ruled himself out of the running to become the next BoE Governor. (Guardian)

GEOPOLITICAL

 

US President Trump is said to have asked Japanese PM Abe for help arranging a summit with Iran. (Newswires) Subsequently, Iranian Foreign Ministry spokesman says it sees no prospect for negotiations with US, according to FARS news. (Newswires)

Israel conducted a rocket strike against Syria in retaliation to anti-aircraft fire at an Israeli jet. (Newswires)

Venezuela President Maduro said more than 88 tons of gold is frozen in London and that 10 boats that were bringing in gasoline were sabotaged. (Newswires)

Turkey has reportedly launched a ground offensive into Iraq, in order to quell PKK terrorists., Anadolu. (Anadolu)

 

EQUITIES

A downbeat session thus far for European equities [Eurostoxx 50 -0.6%] as the region failed to capitalise on the positive momentum seen in Asia. Most major European bourses are experiencing broad-based losses although Italy’s FTSE MIB (-0.9%) underperforms as banking names are weighed on by the decline in BTPs, whilst the UK’s FTSE (Unch) is supported by heavyweight mining names (Rio Tinto +3.2%, BHP +1.8%, Antofagasta +2.2%) profiting from the surge in iron ore price. Thus, the sector is outperforming whilst most of the other sectors are posting broad-based losses. In terms of individual movers, Renault (+0.7%) shares are higher in a continuation of yesterday’s rise due to a potential Renault-Fiat Chrysler merger. Richemont (-0.6%) and Swatch (-0.8%) are subdued amid a Swiss watch export decline of 0.4% Y/Y. Finally, Thyssenkrupp (+3.2%) rose to the top of the DAX amid a rise in steel prices. In terms of some analysis from Nomura Quant, amongst major hedge funds, macro funds are tilting short equities, with overall sentiment on US-China trade discussions on a gradual downtrend. Whilst some short-lived rallies may yet come, little optimism is seen on the immediate horizon, and it is unlikely hedge funds and CTAs will be convinced to return to buying. “It also looks likely to us that CTAs will go back to closing out long positions in NASDAQ 100 futures and S&P 500 futures starting today” says Nomura.

E-Cigarette/Tobacco Names – e-cigarette flavourings may damage the cells that line blood vessels and pose a risk for consumers long-term heart health according to a study. (Axios)

FX

USD - The Buck remains off recent key day reversal or retracement lows, but the DXY is still struggling to regain sufficient momentum for an attempt to revisit 98.000 and 2019 peaks reached only last Thursday (98.373). However, in a twist to normal month end trends, equity rebalancing flows may be Dollar supportive this week as at least one preliminary model is signalling a net buy, and especially strong against Sterling vs relatively weak demand against the Yen.

JPY/NOK/SEK - The clear G10 outperformers as Usd/Jpy retreats from 109.50+ highs to test support ahead of 109.00 at a 109.23 Fib amidst a broad downturn in risk sentiment, while the Scandi Crowns continue to derive encouragement from last week’s stellar unemployment developments rather than less upbeat sentiment indicators today. Indeed, Eur/Nok has had a look at 9.2000 ahead of a key downside technical level in the form of the 100 DMA (9.7190), with extra impetus from higher Norwegian oil investment forecasts, while Eur/Sek is back below 10.7000 and has been under 10.6750.

NZD/AUD - The next best majors as the Kiwi holds above 0.6500 vs its US counterpart awaiting the latest RBNZ Financial Stability Report due tomorrow and the Aussie maintains 0.6900+ status ahead of next week’s RBA policy meeting with a 25 bp rate cut all but totally priced in. On that note, Aud/Usd may well be capped by macro offers

CAD/GBP/CHF - All slightly softer vs the Greenback, as the Loonie pivots 1.3450 and trades cautiously into Wednesday’s BoC (full preview available on the Ransquawk Research Suite), while the Pound hovers closer to the base of a 1.2700-1.2655 range in the fall-out from last week’s formal notice of resignation from UK PM May and the weekend EU Parliamentary elections, and with the aforementioned end of May Cable signals hardly helping. In similar vein, the Franc has not been able to glean much, if any traction from much stronger than forecast Swiss GDP, as the Government was quick to caution that one-off factors impacted favourably in Q1 and it would not be raising its full year growth forecast on the back of a bumper first quarter, while April’s trade surplus was smaller than expected. Usd/Chf is firmly above recent lows within a tight 1.0050-35 band and Eur/Chf is also looking more solid on the 1.1200 handle between 1.1245-25 vs sub-big figure levels last week.

EUR - As noted above, the single currency has rebounded off worst levels vs the Franc despite the return of Italian/EU fiscal tensions, and the Euro is also displaying a degree of resilience against the Dollar within 1.1176-1.1200 trading parameters, albeit not convincingly through 30 DMA resistance (1.1196) or beyond 1.1200 to challenge a Fib at 1.1215.

EM - Another marginal move up in the Usd/Cny fix overnight still leaves the spread to Usd/Cnh on a wider trajectory, but the former could be set higher in wake of the PBoC’s move to raise its counter cyclical ‘adjustments’. Elsewhere, the Try has finally reaped some benefit from Monday’s CBRT hike in the RRR, but Turkey is still embroiled in geopolitical and diplomatic conflicts that could see the Lira lurch again.

Swiss Govt. Economist says that the strong Q1 GDP figures don't mean an automatic upgrade to annual forecasts, general environment remains the same. Growth was helped by one-offs, but negatives still present; cite trade war, Brexit and Germany as risks. (Newswires)

 

FIXED INCOME

Some signs of stabilisation in overall risk sentiment via the Dax future reclaiming 12k and 10 year Italian debt getting a reprieve of sorts from EU’s Moscovici and Dombrovskis, have combined to take some of the shine off safe-haven Bunds, Gilts and US Treasuries. However, the core Eurozone bond remains above par having tailed off just ahead of 168.00 at 167.91 (+27 ticks on the day), while its UK equivalent is still over ¼ point ahead and the corresponding 10 year T-note is 11 ticks ahead as the latter 2 hold corrective gains after Monday’s holidays. Ahead, Italy must await for official budget judgement next week before it is out of the EDP firing line, while the PM agenda holds US housing data and supply after satisfactory auctions from Germany and Italy.

 

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures have been relatively resilient to the risk aversion around the market with the former hovering above USD 59/bbl and the latter around USD 70.50/bbl. Of note, there was no WTI settlement yesterday and thus there is a deviation in price change between the two benchmarks. Nevertheless, WTI’s discount to Brent has been gaining more focus, with the WTI/Brent Arb now almost USD -11/bbl. The widening spread is attributed to US stockpiles building keeping WTI subdued, whilst Brent is supported by the Russian oil contamination. Analysts at RBC highlight that physical markets are tight, and inventories are piling up despite the backwardated term structure. “We do not interpret the recent increases as entirely bearish given that the majority of builds from the US to consuming Asia have been deliberate and tactical which has, in turn, kept markets tight” RBC says. Meanwhile, gold (Unch) is flat on the day, but the yellow metal nursed some of its overnight losses as the risk tone deteriorated further, from a technical perspective; immediate levels to the upside include the 50 DMA at 1288.12/oz ahead of the psychological 1290/oz.  Elsewhere, copper remains lacklustre amid the downbeat risk tone, as prices fluctuate on either side of USD 2.70/lb. Finally, Dalian iron ore prices spiked to record highs amid ongoing supply concerns and with stockpiles around 2yr lows.

Russian Energy Minister Novak hopes OPEC and partners will be able to formalise the OPEC+ agreement by June with the adoption of a new charter. (Newswires)

Shanghai Futures Exchange Chairman said they are preparing to launch alumina and gold futures this year. (Newswires)

subject: RBC: “Market outlook, UK PM race and Gilt yields”
content:
• On Friday, UK PM May announced her decision to stand down as party leader as of June 7th, with the decision subsequently trigger a leadership contest. Note, she will stay on as PM until a new leader has been appointed.
  • Boris Johnson is the clear front-runner with a recent Conservative member poll published by the Times putting him in pole position with 39% of the vote with his closest competition being former Brexit -Secretary Dominic Raab on 13%. 
  • From a markets perspective, RBC highlight the importance of the leadership race as being what the odds of a hard Brexit will be and what will be the implication for rates. 
  • Bookmaker quotes imply odds of around 25% for a ‘no deal’ Brexit. RBC do not see a material increase in these odds at this stage, however, they suggest it is hard to see them declining as preparations for a ‘no deal’ exit intensify.  
  • From a BoE perspective, RBC thus suggest that the implied odds of a BoE hike are titled to the downside. Global factors (US-China trade war) could also play a key role in this view. Furthermore, the BoE has more room to cut than other global central banks (50bps above all-time lows), whilst maintaining an official hiking bias.  
  • Ultimately, RBC are not looking for a rate cut at this stage but suggest there is more space for markets to push money market rates in this direction.
  • Implied break-even inflation rates in the UK are notably higher than in either the US or the EUR market, leaving nominal Gilt yields and GBP swap rates exposed to the downside. 
  • RBC recommends outperformance trades versus the EUR market in the 5y space and relative 10y-30y steepeners versus the EUR market and hold on to those view. RBC also look for UK break-eve tighteners and look for good entry levels in outright terms of versus the US, but believe there will be better entry levels ahead

  • They have observed long-short funds, since the start of May, scaling back their aggregate long position in cyclical sectors; and instead are building a growing long position in defensive sectors.
  • Long-short funds have also been seen “leaning long” on IT stocks this month, vs the short leanings in April.
  • This gives rise to the suggestion that active market players are cautious about the US economy but are looking to buy dips in the IT sector.
  • Nomura note, however, that the aforementioned long-short funds may see some trouble if the US-China negotiations give rise to news negative for the tech sector
  • With CTAs building short positions in Asian equity markets, suggestions are building about uncertain Chinese economic prospects. Nomura also see the upcoming Chinese PMI as another catalyst for selling

subject: Gilts and Short Sterling futures spring back into action
content: Little time to rest on laurels or ease their way back from the long holiday weekend as UK bonds bounce sharply in line with the 3 month strip in catch-up trade and with an extra fillip on Brexit and domestic political grounds. Gilts returned to Liffe at 130.17 and after a very early wobble subsequently extended gains to 46 ticks at 130.37 from last Friday’s 129.91 close, while STIR contracts have been 4 ticks ahead at best. Turning to Tuesday’s agenda, only BBA mortgage applications for April, but a packed docket elsewhere and shaky risk sentiment overall keeping safe-havens propped up. Back to debt futures, note that some chart proponents and technical analysis has switched to the Sep19 future, but volumes are still a smidge larger in Jun19 at present.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

28th May 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mostly higher but with gains capped as trade slowly picked up from the holiday lull in the US and UK. ASX 200 (+0.5%) was positive with the gains led by the tech sector and as miners cheered the recent upside in commodities including Chinese benchmark iron ore prices which hit record highs. Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) was underpinned by corporate news flow with Tokyo Electron lifted from a JPY 150bln buyback, while Nissan and Mitsubishi Motors gained following the recent merger proposal between alliance partner Renault and Fiat. Hang Seng (+0.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.9%) gained following a substantial liquidity injection of CNY 150bln by the PBoC which placed the ongoing trade uncertainty on the back seat.

FTSE

Shell (RDSA LN) – Co. has begun renegotiating oil contracts with Nigeria which could lead to major energy Cos generating billions dollars less in revenues from lucrative offshore blocks. (FT)

ITV (ITV LN) – Sources stated that negotiations between the Co. and BBC have grown tense amid a face-off over their joint streaming service Britbox, which was seen to rival Netflix. Sources added that ITV committed more fully to the subscription service than BBC. (FT)

Aviva (AV/ LN) – Co. reportedly plans to unveil a large shake-up of its UK business next week. One option was to split the Co.’s largest operation, its UK business, into two parts. One would contain the life insurance division whilst the other would be non-life insurance, i.e. car and home cover, according to Observers. (FT)

AstraZeneca (AZN LN) – Co. are reportedly to unveil encouraging trial data from two of their cancer drugs, Lynparza and Imfinzi, at the American Society of Clinical Oncology next week. (Telegraph)

Vodafone (VOD LN) – Co. have tested technology which allows them to send no-fly zone information to drones, and force the drones to land if it is necessary. (Telegraph)

Insurance/Auto Names – The Association of British Insurers shows that payouts for stolen cars had risen 14% in 12 months, to the highest quarterly level since 2012. (Times)

UK Banking Names – EY Item Club has warned that the Banking industry should anticipate further pain over the next two years, due to Brexit uncertainty and the subdued economic picture. (Telegraph)

Mining names – Overnight, copper saw marginal gains amid the positive risk tone in China while Chinese benchmark iron ore prices surged to a record high amid ongoing supply concerns and stockpiles at a 2yr low.

Oil names – Oil prices held steady and held onto most of the prior day’s gains with Brent crude back above USD 70/bbl whilst WTI reclaimed the USD 59/bbl.

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Thomas Cook (TCG LN) – Co. are attempting to please investors with a new plan to transform itself into a holiday market place, which will see the Co. focus on its website, but it will continue to own hotels which will be kept off the balance sheet via a “hotel fund”. City source noted that many investors are buoyed at the Co’s plans. (Telegraph)

Bovis Homes (BVS LN) – Co. is reportedly mulling a fresh bid for lion’s share of Galliford Try after its housebuilding rejected the initial offer for its new homes division and regeneration business as Bovis’ offer undervalued both units. (Times) 

BROKER MOVES

THOMAS COOK (TCG LN) UPGRADED TO HOLD FROM SELL AT BERENBERG

ANGLO AMERICAN (AAL LN) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT HSBC

ANTOFAGASTA (ANTO LN) UPGRADED TO HOLD FROM REDUCE AT HSBC

LLOYDS BANKING GROUP (LLOY LN) UPGRADED TO OUTPERFORM FROM NEUTRAL AT DAVY RESEARCH

DAX

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY)/ Commerzbank (CBK GY) – German banking authorities will require German banks to set aside more provisions from July to balance the risk of a slowing economy. The Financial Stability Board stated that the banks will have to set aside a combined USD 5.3bln more in core capital. (Newswires)

BMW (BMW GY) – Co. has launched the BMW Motorrad “Concept R18” which is expected to rival Harley Davidson. (Newswires) 

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Lufthansa (LHA GY) – Lufthansa Cargo will now adjust its schedule in an attempt to reduce its overall offering for Q2 and Q3. Furthermore, the service will be cut across the flight programme, in line with trends in demand. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

CAC

Vivendi (VIV FP) – Co’s Canal+ has agreed to purchase the pay-TV operator M7 group from private equity firm Astorg Partners SAS for just over EUR 1bln in an attempt to expand into more European countries and increase subscribes by almost 20mln. (FT) Separately, an investigation has determined that no concrete was spilt into the Seine by a Co. construction plant; follows on from a broadcast report which alleges the Co. dumped concrete into the Seine. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

PAN EUROPE

Ubi Banca (UBI IM) – Patto dei Mille, a group of 95 investors, stated that it had almost doubled its stake in the Co. to 6.94%. (Newswires)

OMV (OMV AV) – Co. have reorganised their downstream business, which is to be divided into refining-petrochemicals and marketing/trading. (Newswires)

SMI

OTHER SWISS COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

SCANDINAVIA 

BROKER MOVES

US

US markets were closed yesterday due to Memorial Day.

RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 28th May 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian indices are moderately higher following on from yesterday’s holiday lull, with Chinese indices supported by a substantial PBoC liquidity injection
  • In FX, DXY extended on gains as its major counterparts EUR/USD and GBP/USD languished following a pullback below 1.1200 and 1.2700 respectively
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German GFK Sentiment and import prices, EZ Consumer Confidence (final), US Consumer Confidence, supply from Italy, Germany and the US

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were mostly higher but with gains capped as trade slowly picked up from the holiday lull in the US and UK. ASX 200 (+0.5%) was positive with the gains led by the tech sector and as miners cheered the recent upside in commodities including Chinese benchmark iron ore prices which hit record highs. Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) was underpinned by corporate news flow with Tokyo Electron lifted from a JPY 150bln buyback, while Nissan and Mitsubishi Motors gained following the recent merger proposal between alliance partner Renault and Fiat. Hang Seng (+0.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.9%) gained following a substantial liquidity injection of CNY 150bln by the PBoC which placed the ongoing trade uncertainty on the back seat. 10yr JGBs were steady as they mirrored the sideways trade in T-note futures although saw mild support following the results from the 40yr JGB auction where the b/c was firmer than previous and as 40yr yields hit their lowest levels since September 2016.

PBoC injected CNY 150bln via 7-day reverse repos for a net daily injection of CNY 70bln. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8973 (Prev. 6.8924)

Chinese President Xi said China will increase access to further sectors. There were separate comments from a securities regulator official that China is looking to widen access for foreign investors to the futures market. (Newswires)

UK/EU

ECB's Hansson said ECB should be less generous in pricing the TLTROs and that a less generous loan should signal policy normalisation, while he added that tiering ECB rates would risk overcomplicating ECB policy. (Newswires)

Austrian Chancellor Kurz was ousted after losing a no confidence vote. (Newswires)

UK Foreign Secretary Hunt states that any PM who attempts to take Britain out of the EU without a deal will trigger a general election, which leads to the risk of Conservative Party ‘extinction’. Brexit Party leader Farage warning that the new Tory leader must take Britain out of the EU by October, or the Brexit Party will ‘fight every seat’ at the next general election. (Telegraph/Times)

Agustín Carstens, the former finance minister and head of Mexico’s central bank has ruled himself out of the running to become the next BoE Governor. (Guardian)

FX

 

Price action was relatively rangebound amid a lack of key data releases and recent holiday closures, although the DXY extended on the prior day’s gains as its major counterparts EUR/USD and GBP/USD languished following a pullback below 1.1200 and 1.2700 respectively. EUR was pressured at the start of the week amid widening Bund/BTP yield differentials after reports the EC might open up proceedings on Italy over high debt, while GBP remained uninspired after the long weekend and Brexit Party’s strong showing at the European Parliamentary elections. USD/JPY traded indecisively and antipodeans were steady as they patiently await the RBNZ Financial Stability Report and Governor Orr comments in tomorrow’s session, as well as Australia Capex data on Thursday and a widely anticipated RBA rate cut next week.

 

COMMODITIES

 

Commodities were mixed with oil prices steady as they held on to the prior day’s gains in which WTI reclaimed the USD 59.00/bbl level and after Brent crude surged 2% on Monday to above USD 70.00/bbl, while there was also reports Russia’s Energy Minister Novak hopes OPEC+ agreement will be formalized next month. Gold was slightly pressured by a firmer greenback and copper prices saw marginal gains amid the positive tone in China, as well as strength in Chinese benchmark iron prices which surged to a record high due to ongoing supply concerns and with stockpiles around 2-year lows.

Russian Energy Minister Novak hopes OPEC and partners will be able to formalise the OPEC+ agreement by June with the adoption of a new charter. (Newswires)

Shanghai Futures Exchange Chairman said they are preparing to launch alumina and gold futures this year. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

 

US President Trump is said to have asked Japanese PM Abe for help arranging a summit with Iran. (Newswires)

Israel conducted a rocket strike against Syria in retaliation to anti-aircraft fire at an Israeli jet. (Newswires)

Venezuela President Maduro said more than 88 tons of gold is frozen in London and that 10 boats that were bringing in gasoline were sabotaged. (Newswires) 

US

US Markets were closed for Memorial Day.
